questions.text: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs); BMI is 16 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Funduscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus retinitis is an AIDS-defining condition that most commonly affects patients with a CD4 count < 50/mm3. Funduscopic findings in CMV retinitis are described as having a “pizza pie” appearance because of a distinct mixture of red and white lesions. The red spots are retinal hemorrhages. The white spots are granular perivascular white opacities around retinal vessels that resemble cotton-wool spots. In the early stages of the disease, vision may still be unaffected even though funduscopic findings are already present. If left untreated, CMV retinitis progresses rapidly and patients develop painless vision loss or scotomas depending on the location of the retinal lesions and whether there is retinal detachment.

See “Ophthalmologic complications of HIV” table.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

There are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).

These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnosis of herpes simplex keratitis is based on a clinical history of infection with herpes simplex virus and slit lamp findings showing dendritic lesions of the cornea. Symptoms include pain, blurry vision, and watering of the eye, none of which is present in this patient. Moreover, the retina is unaffected and funduscopic findings are normal in herpes simplex keratitis.
Image Description:

Slit lamp photography with fluorescein application under cobalt blue light filter

Fluorescein staining of the cornea under blue light shows green fluorescence of geographic epithelial defects. These defects are characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis, though less common than dendritic epithelial defects, which represent the hallmark of herpes simplex keratitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection that typically occurs when CD4 counts are below 100. On examination, this patient's yellow-white opacities may be mistaken for toxoplasma retinitis. However, this patient's opacities are perivascular (located around the retinal vessels), while toxoplasma lesions are nonvascular (their distribution is not related to the vessels). Additionally, patients with toxoplasma retinitis most commonly present with eye pain.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

D) INCORRECT:

HIV retinopathy is a microvascular disorder of the retina that occurs in about 60% of patients with AIDS. It classically manifests with cotton-wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and microaneurysms. This patient's perivascular yellow-white opacities could be confused with cotton-wool spots. The key differences are that cotton-wool spots are smaller in size, and tend to resolve on their own without progression. Vision is typically unaffected in HIV retinopathy, which helps to distinguish it from other causes of eye disease in HIV-positive patients. The “black spots” seen by this patient also suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a HIV-positive patient

Opaque white patches are present along the retinal blood vessels in the upper third of the image (a prominent example is indicated by the arrow).

These small perivascular opacities are called “cotton-wool spots” and are consistent with noninfectious retinopathy in HIV patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella zoster virus retinitis is a rare disease of the retina that begins by affecting the periphery, causing severe pain, retinal necrosis, and vision loss. If this patient had VZV retinitis, he would have eye pain and fundoscopy would not show yellow-white opacities.
questions.hint: This patient with HIV has an opportunistic infection typically only seen in severely immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fever for 2 days. He also has a nonproductive cough. He does not have chest pain or headache. He has chronic myeloid leukemia and had a bone marrow transplant 3 months ago. His current medications include busulfan, mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, and methylprednisolone. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles. The spleen tip is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4,400/mm3



Platelet count
160,000/mm3



Serum



Glucose
78 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.1 mg/dL


D-dimer
96 ng/mL (N ≤ 250)


pp65 antigen
positive


Galactomannan antigen
negative


Urinalysis is normal. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and is commonly used in the treatment of bacterial pneumonia, including atypical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia can manifest with fever, cough, dyspnea, and diffuse (versus lobar) infiltrates on chest x-ray, the finding of pp65 antigen in serum suggests CMV pneumonia, for which levofloxacin is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir is the treatment of choice for mild to moderate CMV infection and for prophylaxis in transplant recipients at risk for CMV infection. This patient, however, shows findings consistent with CMV pneumonia, which is a severe infection that carries a high mortality risk, making a more aggressive treatment option more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of varicella (VZV) and herpes (HSV) infections. Although these viruses can also cause pulmonary disease in immunocompromised patients, this patient tested positive for pp65 antigen, a marker of active CMV replication. While CMV also belongs to the family of Herpesviridae, acyclovir does not effectively treat CMV pneumonia because CMV lacks the enzyme thymidine kinase, which is required to take up and activate acyclovir.

D) INCORRECT:

Heparin is the treatment of choice for acute pulmonary embolism, which may also manifest with coughing, tachycardia, and shortness of breath. However, this patient's D-dimer levels are low (< 500 ng/mL), ruling out acute PE.

E) CORRECT:

Intravenous ganciclovir (adjusted to renal function), possibly combined with intravenous immunoglobulin therapy, is the first-line treatment for severe and life-threatening CMV infection (e.g., CMV pneumonia). In patients with ganciclovir resistance, IV foscarnet is the preferred agent.

The diagnosis of CMV pneumonia is confirmed if CMV is detected in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid or lung tissue samples following transbronchial biopsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of atypical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia can manifest with fever, cough, dyspnea, and diffuse (versus lobar) infiltrates on chest x-ray, the finding of pp65 antigen in serum suggests CMV pneumonia, for which azithromycin is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and x-ray findings together with pp65 antigen in serum are consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., following bone marrow transplant).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of diarrhea and a 2.2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. During the past week, he has had six small bloody stools daily. He has HIV, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hypertension. Current medications include chlorthalidone, omeprazole, emtricitabine, tenofovir, and efavirenz. He reports taking efavirenz irregularly. He is employed as a sales manager and regularly flies to South America. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (143 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 116/69 mm Hg. The abdomen is scaphoid. Bowel sounds are normal. His leukocyte count is 6000/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h, and CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 44/mm3. Colonoscopy shows areas of inflammation scattered throughout the colon with friability, granularity, and shallow linear ulcerations. The intervening mucosa between areas of inflammation appears normal. A biopsy specimen shows basophilic intranuclear inclusions and a surrounding halo. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a CD4 count < 50 cells/mm3, which increases the risk of infection by bacteria of the Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex (MAC). MAC infection may present with weight loss and diarrhea. However, diarrhea is usually nonbloody and is typically associated with other nonspecific constitutional symptoms such as a fever > 39°C, night sweats, and cough.

B) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can cause weight loss and bloody diarrhea and it also causes ulcerations interspersed between normal mucosa (skip lesions) on colonoscopy, similar to those described in this patient. However, Crohn disease does not cause the intranuclear inclusions seen on this patient's biopsy. Additionally, inflammatory markers would likely be elevated in Crohn disease, but this patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate is normal.

C) CORRECT:

Severe cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection (including CMV colitis) may occur in HIV-infected patients with a CD4 count < 50 cells/mm3. CMV colitis typically presents with watery and explosive diarrhea, but if the distal colon becomes involved, diarrhea may become bloody. Suspected CMV colitis can be confirmed via the detection of characteristic linear lesions on colonoscopy and owl eye inclusions on biopsy. Options for empiric treatment of CMV infection include foscarnet, ganciclovir, and cidofovir.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is a possible cause of infectious diarrhea. Although this patient has a history of travel to an endemic area (South America), the absence of jaundice, nausea and vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, or hepatomegaly makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, HAV infection would not cause this patient's colonoscopy or biopsy findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Diarrhea is a common adverse effect of many medications, including antiretroviral drugs. While drug-induced diarrhea should be considered in a patient on antiretroviral therapy, medications would not cause this patient's colonoscopy or biopsy findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Although C. parvum could cause diarrhea and weight loss in a patient with HIV, it rarely causes bloody diarrhea. Additionally, it does not explain the linear lesions found on colonoscopy or the biopsy findings.

G) INCORRECT:

HIV-associated enteropathy can cause chronic diarrhea in HIV-positive patients. However, HIV-associated enteropathy is a diagnosis of exclusion that is made only when no other cause of diarrhea can be identified. A biopsy would reveal mild mucosal atrophy with a decreased number of mitotic figures. Owl eye inclusions suggest a different diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Clostridioides difficile is a common bacterial cause of diarrhea following antibiotic and/or proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. Although this patient does report using a PPI (omeprazole), he lacks the characteristic pseudomembranes of C. difficile colitis on colonoscopy. Additionally, C. difficile does not cause the owl eye inclusions seen on this patient's biopsy.
questions.hint: What causes bloody diarrhea and cells appearing as owl's eyes in a person with AIDS?

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of progressively blurred vision. He also reports seeing flashing lights in his visual field. He does not have any pain. The patient has not been examined by a physician in several years. He appears emaciated. Examination shows right conjunctival injection. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Funduscopic examination of the right eye is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 46/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are considered first-line therapy for CMV retinitis, a condition that can cause blurring, vision loss, floaters, and photopsia (flashing lights). It usually occurs unilaterally (right eye in this patient) but can affect the other eye if untreated. Alternative agents include foscarnet and cidofovir. In patients with severe infection (e.g., lesions < 1.5 mm from the fovea or adjacent to the optic nerve head), intravitreal therapy with ganciclovir or foscarnet should also be considered. Other CMV infections that develop in patients with CD4+ T-cell count < 50/mm3 include CMV esophagitis, CMV colitis, CMV pneumonitis, and CMV encephalitis.

Additionally, this patient should be started on antiretroviral therapy to increase his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

There are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).

These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections, which can affect the eyes and manifest with visual blurring and conjunctivitis. However, HSV keratitis and VZV keratitis both manifest with corneal ulcers and are typically painful. The extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient are not common manifestations of HSV or VZV ocular infections. Acyclovir is ineffective against CMV.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat syphilis, which can affect the uvea and optic nerve (and, less commonly, other ocular structures). Though ocular syphilis causes conjunctival injection and decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain and photophobia. Syphilitic uveitis also causes perivascular retinal inflammation and depigmentation of the retina, unlike the extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient. Additionally, isolated ocular findings are rare; patients typically have other findings of primary or secondary syphilis (e.g., chancre, condyloma lata, or generalized lymphadenopathy). Penicillin G is ineffective against CMV.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a patient with HIV and syphilis

Papilledema with blurred disk margins (black arrows) is visible, indicating papillitis. In addition, tortuous vessels, which represent an unspecific sign, can be seen.

Ocular manifestations of syphilis include a wide range of inflammatory intraocular conditions, in this case as papillitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used to treat shingles as well as genital and labial herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. Although varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and HSV can affect the eyes and cause visual blurring and conjunctivitis, these infections both manifest with corneal ulcers and are typically painful. Famciclovir is neither approved for ocular manifestations of VZV or HSV nor is it effective against CMV.

E) INCORRECT:

Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are used in combination to treat toxoplasmosis, which can cause chorioretinitis. Although toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis results in decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain. Additionally, unlike the perivascular retinal lesions seen in this patient, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis causes yellow-white, fluffy lesions in a nonvascular distribution. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are ineffective against CMV.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

F) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is commonly used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis in patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm3. It is also used to treat Pneumocystis choroiditis, a condition typically seen in patients with disseminated Pneumocystis infections. Pneumocystis choroiditis manifests with multiple, bilateral, yellow-white choroidal lesions that spare the retina. Visual changes are uncommon. TMP-SMX is ineffective against CMV.
questions.hint: Funduscopy in this patient, whose depressed CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is almost certainly secondary to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), shows fluffy, hemorrhagic, perivascular retinal lesions that radiate out from the optic disc (pizza-pie appearance). These symptoms and findings are characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of fever, headaches, and profound fatigue. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3 (15% atypical lymphocytes)


Serum



Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
90 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
60 U/L


Heterophile antibody assay
negative


EBV viral capsid antigen (VCA) antibodies
negative


HIV antibody
negative


In an immunocompromised host, the causal organism of this patient's symptoms would most likely cause which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Multiple cerebral abscesses with surrounding edema
Purplish skin nodules on the distal extremities
Non-scrapable white patches on the lateral tongue
Linear ulcers near the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple cerebral abscesses with surrounding edema are seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii in immunocompromised individuals. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most common neurological AIDS-defining condition. In immunocompetent patients, toxoplasmosis is asymptomatic in ∼ 90% of cases but can cause symptoms of mononucleosis (e.g., fever, fatigue, headache). However, it typically presents with bilateral, symmetrical, nontender cervical lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, it would not be expected to cause > 10% atypical lymphocytes.
Image Description:

A: CT head (with contrast, axial plane); B: MRI head (with contrast, T1-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with AIDS

CT shows a ring-enhancing lesion (arrow) in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The two smaller cerebral lesions seen on MRI (arrows) contain eccentric enhancing nodules.

This appearance has been termed the “eccentric (or asymmetric) target sign” and is considered characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse pulmonary infiltrates with pneumatoceles in immunocompromised patients are seen in pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. PCP is an AIDS-defining condition that is is also seen in primary immunodeficiency disorders, malignancies, and malnutrition. Immunocompetent individuals are very rarely susceptible to infection with Pneumocystis carinii.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

There is widespread increased attenuation of the lung parenchyma with preservation of bronchial and vascular markings (ground-glass opacification; green overlay). In the posterior lungs, markings are obscured by consolidation (red overlay). Scattered small gas-filled cystic spaces (pneumatoceles; examples indicated by white arrows) are present bilaterally.

Extensive ground-glass opacification is a frequent feature of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and may be accompanied by pneumatoceles.

S: sternum; AA: ascending Aorta; PT: pulmonary trunk; DA: descending aorta; V: vertebra; RMB: right mainstem bronchus; LMB: left mainstem bronchus

C) INCORRECT:

Purplish skin nodules on the distal extremities in immunocompromised patients are suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, which is an an AIDS-defining condition caused by infection with HHV-8. Acute primary infection with HHV-8 has also been described in immunocompetent individuals, specifically children and men who have sex with men, but the disease course in these groups typically involves 2–8 days of maculopapular rash and fever, unlike the symptoms and prolonged course seen here.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

D) INCORRECT:

Non-scrapable white patches on the lateral tongue in immunocompromised patients are suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia, an HIV-associated condition caused by EBV infection. In immunocompetent individuals, EBV is the primary cause of infectious mononucleosis, which is unlikely in this case because of the patient's negative monospot (heterophile antibody test) and EBV VCA antibodies. CMV infection is not associated with development of oral hairy leukoplakia.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

E) CORRECT:

Although CMV is asymptomatic in the majority of cases involving immunocompetent individuals, it can cause CMV mononucleosis in up to 10% of the population. In contrast, CMV infection in immunocompromised individuals can cause CMV esophagitis, which manifests as linear ulcers near the lower esophageal sphincter, and many other complications, including CMV pneumonia, CMV retinitis, and CMV encephalitis (all of which are AIDS-defining conditions).
questions.hint: The patient's constitutional symptoms, fever, splenomegaly, and the finding of atypical lymphocytosis with ≥ 10% lymphocytes and mild elevation of transaminases are characteristic of mononucleosis. The absence of exudative pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy, in combination with the negative monospot test (heterophile antibody assay) and negative EBV VCA antibodies, make cytomegalovirus (CMV) the most likely causal pathogen.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is commonly used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis in patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm3. It is also used to treat Pneumocystis choroiditis, a condition typically seen in patients with disseminated Pneumocystis infection. Pneumocystis choroiditis manifests with multiple, bilateral, yellow-white choroidal lesions that spare the retina. Visual changes are uncommon. TMP-SMX is ineffective against CMV.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat ocular syphilis, which primarily affects the uvea and usually causes painful vision loss. Although this condition can result in perivascular retinal inflammation and retinal depigmentation, the extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient are not typical. Additionally, isolated ocular syphilis is rare; patients typically have other findings of syphilis (e.g., chancre, condyloma lata, generalized lymphadenopathy). Penicillin G is ineffective against CMV.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex keratitis, herpes zoster ophthalmicus, and varicella zoster retinitis. These conditions are more likely to occur in individuals with HIV infection but cause painful vision loss. Varicella zoster retinitis causes vitreous opacification and yellow-white retinal patches starting from the periphery rather than the extensive retinal hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient. Patients with herpes simplex keratitis and herpes zoster ophthalmicus would have corneal ulceration on slit lamp examination. Acyclovir is not effective against CMV.

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfadiazine-pyrimethamine is used to treat toxoplasmosis, which can cause chorioretinitis. Although toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis results in decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain. Additionally, unlike the perivascular retinal lesions seen in this patient, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis causes yellow-white, fluffy lesions in a nonvascular distribution. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are ineffective against CMV.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

E) CORRECT:

Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are considered first-line therapy for CMV retinitis. which usually occurs unilaterally but can affect the other eye if untreated. Alternative agents include foscarnet and cidofovir. In patients with severe infection (e.g., lesions < 1.5 mm from the fovea or adjacent to the optic nerve head), intravitreal therapy with ganciclovir or foscarnet should also be considered. In HIV-positive patients, manifestations of severe CMV disease such as retinitis, esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis usually occur when the CD4+ T-cell count is < 50/mm3. Patients with HIV infection should also be started on antiretroviral therapy to increase the CD4+ T-cell count.

See “Ophthalmologic complications of HIV” table.
questions.hint: Painless vision loss with photopsia (flashing lights) and the funduscopic findings of fluffy, hemorrhagic, perivascular retinal lesions that radiate out from the optic disc (pizza-pie appearance) are characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, which typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. A history of high-risk sexual behavior, oral candidiasis (white plaques that are easily scraped off), and findings of CMV retinitis suggest an HIV infection in this patient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man reports a 13.6-kg weight loss during the past 6 months. He has no significant medical history but has not been seen in a health care setting since he was a teenager. In addition to his weight loss, he complains of fever with night sweats, abdominal pain, and severe diarrhea. He has noted frank blood in his stools and has substantial pain with defecation.
On examination, he appears thin and has evidence of temporal wasting. There are multiple white patches on his tongue. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and his cardiac examination is unremarkable. His abdomen is soft and nontender without evidence of hepatosplenomegaly. The rectal examination is painful for the patient and reveals dark-brown to black stool.
Laboratory findings are as follows:

An HIV test is positive. Colonoscopy shows areas of submucosal hemorrhage, edema, and multiple ulcers. Biopsies are performed.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although ulcerative colitis can occur in people with HIV, it is quite rare, and there is some evidence to suggest that the disease is more quiescent with very low CD4-cell counts.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptosporidiosis and giardiasis both cause enteritis and typically manifest with large-volume, watery diarrhea rather than tenesmus, pain on defecation, or bloody diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptosporidiosis and giardiasis both cause enteritis and typically manifest with large-volume, watery diarrhea rather than tenesmus, pain on defecation, or bloody diarrhea.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic diarrhea in an immunocompromised patient can be caused by infection, neoplasm, or inflammatory disease. Enteritis, or small-bowel disease, is characterized by large-volume watery diarrhea with crampy abdominal pain. Colitis, or large-bowel disease, is associated with tenesmus, proctitis, and frequent small-volume bowel movements. This patient's symptoms suggest colitis; cytomegalovirus is the most common opportunistic pathogen causing colitis. Cytomegalovirus is characterized by ulcerative lesions that, when biopsied, show characteristic intranuclear inclusions. Treatment is intravenous ganciclovir.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a person with HIV who has a CD4 count < 50 cells/mm3, chronic diarrhea, tenesmus, and colonic ulcers on endoscopy is cytomegalovirus colitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopically, Kaposi sarcoma can be recognized by classic submucosal hemorrhagic lesions and is rarely symptomatic, with the exception of potential bleeding complications.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman who received a kidney transplant from a deceased donor 15 months ago reports a 4-day history of fever, vomiting, abdominal cramping, and profuse watery diarrhea, with at least 10 bowel movements daily. She has also noted bright-red blood mixed with her stool. Before the transplantation, she had developed end-stage kidney disease related to uncontrolled type 1 diabetes. Her post-transplant course has been uncomplicated, with no episodes of rejection.
Her immunosuppressive regimen consists of tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. She completed a standard 6-month course of valganciclovir post-transplant for cytomegalovirus prophylaxis; the donor had positive immunoglobulin G serology for cytomegalovirus, and the recipient was negative.
On examination, the patient’s temperature is 38.9°C, her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Her oral mucosa is dry. Her abdomen is diffusely tender to deep palpation, particularly in the left lower quadrant.
A flexible sigmoidoscopy demonstrates severe colitis with multiple clean-based ulcers.
Which one of the following treatments should be initiated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a major cause of morbidity in solid-organ transplant recipients; the highest risk of disease occurs when the transplant recipient is seronegative for CMV but the donor is seropositive. Symptoms of gastrointestinal CMV disease include fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Esophagitis, gastritis, colitis, and ulcerations can be seen. Sigmoidoscopy typically demonstrates severe colitis with multiple clean-based ulcers. With the widespread use of CMV prophylaxis, an increase in late-onset CMV disease (occurring > 6 months after transplantation) has been seen.

The treatment of choice for invasive CMV disease is either intravenous ganciclovir at a dose of 5 mg/kg twice daily or oral valganciclovir at a dose of 900 mg twice daily (adjusted for kidney function). Intravenous ganciclovir is preferred if there is vomiting, severe diarrhea, or other concerns for gastrointestinal absorption.

Key learning point: Cytomegalovirus colitis in a solid-organ transplant recipient is optimally treated with either intravenous ganciclovir or oral valganciclovir.

B) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, fluconazole, and amphotericin are not appropriate for a patient whose presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of CMV infection and is not typical of bacterial or fungal colitis. Nevertheless, stool studies to exclude bacterial infection are appropriate in any immunosuppressed patient with diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, fluconazole, and amphotericin are not appropriate for a patient whose presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of CMV infection and is not typical of bacterial or fungal colitis. Nevertheless, stool studies to exclude bacterial infection are appropriate in any immunosuppressed patient with diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Although acyclovir has good activity against herpes simplex viruses and varicella zoster virus, it should not be used to treat CMV disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, fluconazole, and amphotericin are not appropriate for a patient whose presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of CMV infection and is not typical of bacterial or fungal colitis. Nevertheless, stool studies to exclude bacterial infection are appropriate in any immunosuppressed patient with diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and ulcerative colitis reports 3 weeks of left-lower-quadrant pain and frequent bloody diarrhea. Five weeks ago, he was started on prednisone 40 mg twice daily for a flare-up of his colitis and initially improved. However, his symptoms have worsened during the past 3 weeks and are now associated with low-grade fevers. He has had no nausea, vomiting, or other new symptoms.
His ulcerative colitis was diagnosed by biopsy 2 years ago and, at that time, was limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon. The disease was well controlled on azathioprine until the current symptoms arose. His last colonoscopy 6 months ago showed inactive colitis in the rectum only.
On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C, and his heart rate is 92 beats per minute. His abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation without rebounding or guarding. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
His leukocyte count is 8600 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), and a comprehensive metabolic panel is within normal limits. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows pancolitis. Tests for Clostridioides difficile in the stool are negative, as are bacterial stool cultures.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Start empiric intravenous glucocorticoids without additional evaluation
Order stool culture and serum PCR testing for cytomegalovirus
Repeat testing for Clostridioides difficile in the stool, and start empiric oral vancomycin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An examination of the colon with biopsy is the most appropriate way to definitively diagnose the cause of this patient’s acute colitis. When a patient with previously stable inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) has an acute colitis that is unresponsive to increased immunosuppressive therapy, a new infectious process should be considered.

Clostridioides difficile has already been ruled out in this case, and bacterial stool cultures were also negative. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is therefore the most likely culprit because it can cause tissue-invasive disease such as colitis, particularly in patients who are taking multiple immunosuppressive medications. The symptoms of CMV colitis are similar to those of an IBD flare but tend to worsen, as in this case, when immunosuppression is increased. Most cases of CMV reactivation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease occur as a result of glucocorticoid therapy.

The gold standard for diagnosing tissue CMV is a biopsy, usually obtained during a sigmoidoscopy or a colonoscopy, with specific immunohistochemistry staining for CMV. Although serum CMV polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing is less invasive, it is not an appropriate test when CMV colitis is suspected because it is neither sensitive nor specific for this diagnosis. A negative serum CMV PCR does not exclude tissue-invasive disease, and a positive serum CMV PCR can be seen in the absence of tissue-invasive disease. Similarly, CMV culture can be positive in the carrier state and also falsely negative. A colonoscopy is considered more dangerous than a sigmoidoscopy in the setting of an acute colitis because of the increased risk of perforation. In this patient with pancolitis, sigmoidoscopy should provide adequate opportunity for tissue sampling.

Key learning point: The most likely etiology of an acute pancolitis in a patient whose inflammatory bowel disease has worsened despite high-dose glucocorticoid therapy and who has negative results on bacterial stool cultures and Clostridioides difficile testing is cytomegalovirus colitis; this should be diagnosed with sigmoidoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient’s symptoms have worsened despite increasing immunosuppressive therapy and that his ulcerative colitis was previously well controlled, an infectious process needs to be excluded. Therefore, although starting intravenous glucocorticoids empirically may be reasonable, the patient also needs to be further evaluated for CMV colitis with sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although serum CMV polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing is less invasive, it is not an appropriate test when CMV colitis is suspected because it is neither sensitive nor specific for this diagnosis. A negative serum CMV PCR does not exclude tissue-invasive disease, and a positive serum CMV PCR can be seen in the absence of tissue-invasive disease. Similarly, CMV culture can be positive in the carrier state and also falsely negative.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeating C. difficile testing and starting empiric treatment for C. difficile infection with oral vancomycin would not be helpful because the patient has already had a negative test result.

E) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole and ceftriaxone may be considered in patients with fistulae or abscesses related to their IBD, but there is no evidence that this patient has either of these complications. His symptoms are more likely to be secondary to CMV colitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the office because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs); BMI is 16 kg/m2. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Funduscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus retinitis is an AIDS-defining condition that most commonly affects patients with a CD4 count < 50/mm3. Funduscopic findings in CMV retinitis are described as having a “pizza pie” appearance because of a distinct mixture of red and white lesions. The red spots are retinal hemorrhages. The white spots are granular perivascular white opacities around retinal vessels that resemble cotton-wool spots. In the early stages of the disease, vision may still be unaffected even though funduscopic findings are already present. If left untreated, CMV retinitis progresses rapidly and patients develop painless vision loss or scotomas depending on the location of the retinal lesions and whether there is retinal detachment.

See “Ophthalmologic complications of HIV” table.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

There are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).

These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnosis of herpes simplex keratitis is based on a clinical history of infection with herpes simplex virus and slit lamp findings showing dendritic lesions of the cornea. Symptoms include pain, blurry vision, and watering of the eye, none of which is present in this patient. Moreover, the retina is unaffected and funduscopic findings are normal in herpes simplex keratitis.
Image Description:

Slit lamp photography with fluorescein application under cobalt blue light filter

Fluorescein staining of the cornea under blue light shows green fluorescence of geographic epithelial defects. These defects are characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis, though less common than dendritic epithelial defects, which represent the hallmark of herpes simplex keratitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection that typically occurs when CD4 counts are below 100. On examination, this patient's yellow-white opacities may be mistaken for toxoplasma retinitis. However, this patient's opacities are perivascular (located around the retinal vessels), while toxoplasma lesions are nonvascular (their distribution is not related to the vessels). Additionally, patients with toxoplasma retinitis most commonly present with eye pain.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

D) INCORRECT:

HIV retinopathy is a microvascular disorder of the retina that occurs in about 60% of patients with AIDS. It classically manifests with cotton-wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and microaneurysms. This patient's perivascular yellow-white opacities could be confused with cotton-wool spots. The key differences are that cotton-wool spots are smaller in size, and tend to resolve on their own without progression. Vision is typically unaffected in HIV retinopathy, which helps to distinguish it from other causes of eye disease in HIV-positive patients. The “black spots” seen by this patient also suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a HIV-positive patient

Opaque white patches are present along the retinal blood vessels in the upper third of the image (a prominent example is indicated by the arrow).

These small perivascular opacities are called “cotton-wool spots” and are consistent with noninfectious retinopathy in HIV patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella zoster virus retinitis is a rare disease of the retina that begins by affecting the periphery, causing severe pain, retinal necrosis, and vision loss. If this patient had VZV retinitis, he would have eye pain and fundoscopy would not show yellow-white opacities.
questions.hint: This patient with HIV has an opportunistic infection typically only seen in severely immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fever for 2 days. He also has a nonproductive cough. He has chronic myeloid leukemia and had a bone marrow transplant 3 months ago. His current medications include busulfan, mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, and methylprednisolone. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles. The spleen tip is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies are positive for CMV pp65 antigen. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and is commonly used in the treatment of bacterial pneumonia, including atypical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia can manifest with fever, cough, dyspnea, and diffuse (versus lobar) infiltrates on chest x-ray, the finding of pp65 antigen in serum suggests CMV pneumonia, for which levofloxacin is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir is the treatment of choice for mild to moderate CMV infection and for prophylaxis in transplant recipients at risk for CMV infection. This patient, however, shows findings consistent with CMV pneumonia, which is a severe infection that carries a high mortality risk, making a more aggressive treatment option more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of varicella (VZV) and herpes (HSV) infections. Although these viruses can also cause pulmonary disease in immunocompromised patients, this patient tested positive for pp65 antigen, a marker of active CMV replication. While CMV also belongs to the family of Herpesviridae, acyclovir does not effectively treat CMV pneumonia because CMV lacks the enzyme thymidine kinase, which is required to take up and activate acyclovir.

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous ganciclovir (adjusted to renal function), possibly combined with intravenous immunoglobulin therapy, is the first-line treatment for severe and life-threatening CMV infection (e.g., CMV pneumonia). In patients with ganciclovir resistance, IV foscarnet is the preferred agent.

The diagnosis of CMV pneumonia is confirmed if CMV is detected in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid or lung tissue samples following transbronchial biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of atypical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia can manifest with fever, cough, dyspnea, and diffuse (versus lobar) infiltrates on chest x-ray, the finding of pp65 antigen in serum suggests CMV pneumonia, for which azithromycin is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and x-ray findings together with pp65 antigen in serum are consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., following bone marrow transplant).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of a kidney transplant 6 months ago presents with a 2-week history of severe pain with swallowing and substernal chest pain. He has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) due to poor oral intake. His medications include tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Physical examination is unremarkable, and an oral examination shows no thrush. An upper endoscopy is performed to evaluate his symptoms. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Multiple concentric rings and linear furrows throughout the esophagus
Diffuse, linear, yellow-white plaques adherent to the mucosa
A single, deep ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa in the mid-esophagus
Large, linear, shallow ulcerations in the distal esophagus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These endoscopic findings, sometimes described as esophageal 'trachealization' or a 'feline esophagus,' are pathognomonic for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). EoE is an immune-mediated inflammatory condition, not an opportunistic infection. It typically manifests with dysphagia to solids and food impaction in patients with a history of atopy, rather than the severe odynophagia seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings are characteristic of Candida esophagitis, the most common cause of infectious esophagitis. While it is a frequent opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, the absence of oral thrush on examination makes this diagnosis slightly less likely. Furthermore, Cytomegalovirus is a particularly significant pathogen in the early post-transplant period.

C) INCORRECT:

This finding is most suggestive of pill-induced esophagitis, which can be caused by medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, bisphosphonates, or potassium chloride. Although this patient is on multiple medications, his profound immunosuppression makes an opportunistic infection a much more likely cause of his severe symptoms and significant weight loss.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is severely immunocompromised due to his post-transplant immunosuppressive regimen, placing him at high risk for opportunistic infections. His symptoms of severe odynophagia and substernal chest pain are classic for infectious esophagitis. The endoscopic finding of large, linear, shallow ulcerations, particularly in the mid-to-distal esophagus, is the classic presentation of Cytomegalovirus esophagitis. CMV is a common and serious opportunistic pathogen in solid organ transplant recipients, especially within the first year post-transplant. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy of the ulcer edge showing characteristic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions (owl's eye inclusions). Treatment is with intravenous ganciclovir.

E) INCORRECT:

This description is classic for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) esophagitis, which manifests with multiple, small, well-circumscribed, 'punched-out' ulcers. While HSV is a cause of infectious esophagitis in immunocompromised hosts, this patient's specific risk profile as a recent solid organ transplant recipient makes Cytomegalovirus a more probable cause of severe esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient's status as a solid organ transplant recipient on triple immunosuppressive therapy is the most important clue. Consider the most common opportunistic infections that cause esophagitis in this population and their characteristic endoscopic appearances.
